>So said Vladimir Ritz Bossicard on 2003-08-08 --------------------
>> I'm =
unhappy about the small number of unit tests being written here and 
>> wou=
ld like my colleagues to write more tests.
>
>IMO you first need to convinc=
e developers that they must write tests 
>before showing them how good (or =
bad) the coverage is.
>
>Normal and not test-infected developers will say t=
hat "no, there's no 
>bug in my code!" so it's up to you to show that:
>
>1=
) these bugs exist
>2) they are easy to reproduce (half the work done)
>3) =
once a test is written, it's executed over and over again (no need to 
>loo=
k at printlns output)
>
>How to spot potential bugs?  Try to use PMD and lo=
ok out for unused code 
>(parameters and variables).  A paper from Stanford=
 pointed out that the 
>cause of bugs is often "silly" mistakes (like unuse=
d code).

Another thing you can do is invite yourself into the next debuggi=
ng session and write tests rather than grope around with println(). When th=
e problem is fixed, be sure to say, "At least *that* will never happen agai=
n."

Or invite someone to help you with your next debugging session, if you=
 have any.

Take care.
